questions.text: Which of the following organisms is least likely to be associated with malignancies?
questions.solution:
HPV 6 and 11 are considered low-risk subtypes and are associated mainly with genital warts (condyloma acuminata) and respiratory papillomatosis in both genders.

HPV 16 and 18 are considered high-risk subtypes and are associated with cancer cervix and pre-cancerous cervical lesions. There is also evidence linking HPV 16 and 18 with cancers of the anus, vulva, vagina, penis, and oropharynx.

Important agents associated with malignant conditions:

  • HHV-8 (mainly), cytomegalovirus - Kaposi’s sarcoma
  • Epstein-Barr virus - Burkitt’s lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • HPV 16 and 18 - Cancer cervix
  • HBV and HCV - Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Schistosoma - Bladder carcinoma

questions.text: Which among the following is not a primary method of prevention of carcinoma in the population?
questions.solution:
Screening for cancer is a secondary level of prevention.

This is because it detects the disease at a pre-invasive or pre-malignant stage when the process of carcinogenesis has already started. It thereby aids in further treatment and improved survival. 

Immunization, restricting the use of tobacco and avoiding alcohol are primary levels of prevention because they prevent the start of carcinogenesis.

questions.text: Which of the following women is not at an increased risk of  developing breast cancer in future?

choices.text: A woman who attained menarche at 9 years of age
A woman who has never breastfed in her lifetime
A woman who attained menopause at 56 years of age
A woman who had her first full term pregnancy at 26 years of age

questions.solution:
Women who have their first full-term pregnancy after 30 years of age are at increased risk for breast cancer.

The risk of breast cancer increases with an increase in duration of exposure to estrogen. As progesterone levels are increased during pregnancy, it reduces the risks of conditions that occur due to hyperestrogenemia.

Risk factors for breast cancer:

  • Modifiable risk factors:
    • Age at first live birth (First full-term pregnancy after 30 years)
    • Parity
    • Lack of breastfeeding
    • Obesity
    • Alcohol consumption
    • Tobacco smoking
    • Use of hormone replacement therapy
    • Decreased physical activity
  • Non-modifiable risk factors:
    • Increasing age
    • Early age at menarche (onset of menses before 12 years of age)
    • Menstrual factors
    • Female sex
    • Older age at menopause (onset beyond 55 years of age)
    • Nulliparity
    • Race, ethnicity
    • Genetic predisposition
    • Family history
    • History of radiation exposure

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is at increased risk of breast cancer as she is on hormone replacement therapy. Which of the following is the most sensitive method of screening for this condition?
questions.solution:
Mammography is the most sensitive and specific investigation for detecting breast cancer.

It can detect even small tumors that are missed during a self-breast examination, clinical examination by the physician and ultrasonographic examination.

October is breast cancer awareness month. This is an annual campaign to educate people about breast cancer, the importance of early detection and treatment. In India, breast cancer accounts for 25% to 31% of all cancers in women.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Early diagnosis and treatment is the best level of prevention of breast cancer. It is a secondary level of prevention.

The earlier a disease is diagnosed and treated, the better is the prognosis. The occurrence of secondary cases or any long term disability can be prevented. This is of particular importance in chronic diseases.

Early diagnosis and treatment is not as effective and economical as primary prevention. However, it may be critically important in reducing the high morbidity and mortality in diseases such as essential hypertension, cancer cervix and breast cancer.

questions.text: A patient with Prader-Willi syndrome needs to be evaluated for obesity but the scale for measuring height in your clinic is broken. Which of the following indices can you still use in this situation?
questions.solution:
The corpulence index can be used in this scenario as it is independent of height. The formula for corpulence index is actual weight/ desired weight.

Related Pearl: Indicators for Body fat

The indicators for body fat are:

Body weight: +3SD (standard deviations) from the median weight for height as a cut-off point for obesity. For adults, some people calculate various other indicators such as:

  • Body mass index (Quetelet's index): Weight (kg) / Square of height in metres
  • Ponderal index: Weight (kg)/Height^3 (m)
  • Corpulence index: Actual weight /desirable weight.(Should not exceed 1.2)

Broca's index = Height (cm) - 100 . 

Lorentz's formula 
Ht (cm) - 100 - [ (Ht (cm) - 150) / 2 for women or 4 for men ]

Skinfold thickness: Four sites mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions. The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.

Waist circumference and waist-hip ratio: At the mid point between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. There is an increased risk of metabolic complications for men with a waist circumference~ 102 cm, and women with a waist circumference~ 88 cm. A high WHR (> 1.0 in men and> 0.85 in women) indicates abdominal fat accumulation.

questions.text: The weight of a diabetic woman is 75 kg and her  height is 150 cm. Calculate her BMI.
questions.solution:
The BMI of an individual with a weight of 75 kg and height of 150 cm is 33. It is calculated as follows,

BMI = Weight (in kg) / Height2 (in metre2) = 75 / (1.5)2 = 33.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding waist circumference?

choices.text: The cut-off for normal waist circumference in Indian women is 90 cm
It is measured at the midpoint between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest
It is an approximate index of intra-abdominal and total body fat
It is an indicator of the risk of chronic diseases

questions.solution:
The cut-off value for normal waist circumference in Indian women is 80cm, while in Indian men it is 90cm.

Waist circumference is an approximate indicator of intra-abdominal and total body fat. It is measured at the midpoint between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. It is an indicator of the risk of chronic diseases.

questions.text: According to the WHO, what is the cut-off for visual acuity for blindness?
questions.solution: According to the WHO, blindness is defined as visual acuity of less than 3/60, or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10°, in the better eye with the best possible correction.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of blindness in India?
questions.solution: According to the National Survey on Blindness (2015-2019), cataract is the most common cause of blindness in India accounting for 66.2% of the total cases.

questions.text: You administer vitamin A prophylactically to a 15-month-old child during a routine checkup. What is the level of prevention being achieved here?
questions.solution: Prophylactic administration of vitamin A to a normal child is an example of primary level of prevention. It is done to prevent xerophthalmia.

questions.text: A boy is brought to the ophthalmologist with complaints of dryness in both the eyes and difficulty in reading. On examination, his eye appears as shown in the below image. What is the stage of xerophthalmia according to WHO?
questions.solution:
The finding in the given image is a Bitot's spot. It belongs to WHO class X1 B of vitamin A deficiency.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child on examination shows signs of vitamin A deficiency. What is the dose of vitamin A to be administered to this child?
questions.solution:
2 lakh IU of vitamin A should be administered to a 2-year-old child with vitamin A deficiency.

Dosage of vitamin A in children:

  • 50,000 IU for children less than 6 months of age
  • 1 lakh IU for children between 6 months to 12 months of age
  • 2 lakh IU for children above 12 months of age. 

These doses of vitamin A are to be administered on days 1, 2 and 14 for the treatment of vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of injury-related death?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of injury-related deaths are road traffic accidents, followed by suicide.

According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), trauma is a major cause of death and disability across the world. Every year, 17th October is celebrated as World Trauma Day to highlight the increasing rate of accidents and injuries, across the globe and the need to prevent them.
